sections.content: Building Wealth for Your Little Ones

There's something incredibly powerful about investing for your children. Every dollar you set aside today could be worth many times more by the time they need it. Whether it's for university, their first car, a gap year, or a deposit on a home — starting now gives them a head start that money can't buy later. And the best part? There are special accounts designed exactly for this.

When your child is born, they have something no billionaire can buy: time. An 18-year-old has decades for their money to compound. If you invest just $25 a month from birth, by the time your child turns 18, that could be worth about $12,000. Leave it growing until they're 30 and it could be over $35,000 — from just $25 a month. That's the gift of time combined with compound interest.
Custodial Accounts: Investing in Their Name

A custodial account (sometimes called a UGMA or UTMA account) is an investment account you open in your child's name. You manage it until they reach adulthood (usually 18 or 21, depending on your state). Here's what makes them great:

• No limit on what the money can be used for — university, a car, starting a business, anything
• You control the investments until your child is old enough
• Easy to open at the same platforms we discussed — Fidelity, Vanguard, Schwab
• You can start with as little as $1

The one thing to know: once your child reaches the legal age, the money becomes theirs. It's their account — you're just the custodian until then.

If you're specifically saving for education costs, a 529 plan is like a supercharged savings account. Here's why mums love them:

• Your money grows tax-free (that means you keep more of the gains)
• Withdrawals for education expenses are also tax-free
• You can use it for university tuition, room and board, textbooks, even K-12 private school (up to $10,000/year)
• Grandparents, aunties, and friends can contribute — perfect for birthday gifts
• If one child doesn't use it, you can transfer it to a sibling

A 529 plan with $50 a month from birth could grow to over $24,000 by the time your child starts university. That's a huge chunk of tuition covered.

Custodial accounts are flexible and can be used for anything when your child grows up. 529 plans are specifically for education and grow tax-free. Both let you start with tiny amounts and both harness the power of time. You don't have to choose just one — many families use both.

Here's a real-world example. Imagine it's your daughter's first birthday. Instead of another toy she'll forget about, you open a 529 plan and put in $500 from birthday money from the family. Then you add $30 a month. By the time she's 18, that account could hold over $15,000 — all from small, steady contributions. Now imagine her face when you tell her that her education is taken care of. That's a gift no toy could ever match.

sections.prompt: Take a moment to reflect: what would it mean to you and your family to have an investment account growing for your child right now? How would it feel to hand them that gift when they're 18? Write down your thoughts — this is your "why" and it will keep you motivated on the days when investing feels hard.

sections.content: A quick note on getting started: you can open a custodial account or 529 plan in the same sitting you open your own investment account. Most platforms walk you through it step by step. You'll need your child's name, date of birth, and Social Security number. The whole process takes about 10 minutes. And just like with your own account, set up automatic contributions so you never have to remember to do it.

You've now completed Level 4: Investing 101. Take a moment to appreciate what you've done. You went from wondering what investing even is, to understanding compound interest, index funds, investment accounts, and how to build wealth for your children. You are setting your family up for a completely different financial future. That is extraordinary. Be proud of yourself — you've earned it.
